Please note that HyperNEAT 1.0 C++ by Jason Gauci has been moved to 
this l=
ocation on our eplex site:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/index.php?
option=3Dcom=
_content&task=3Dview&id=3D17&Itemid=3D32#hyperneat1

I want to mention that=
 Jason put a lot of effort in to make this 
package user-friendly, both fro=
m the executable and source code 
standpoint.  It is possible to add experi=
ments or just to play with 
the current experiment, which is quite interest=
ing and has a nice 
GUI.  

The experiment it comes with is the simple visu=
al discrimination 
(identifying the larger square) in our paper

http://epl=
ex.cs.ucf.edu/index.php?
option=3Dcom_content&task=3Dview&id=3D14&Itemid=3D=
28#gauci.gecco07

The package comes with a few actual population files from=
 that 
experiment.  You can load in substrates and play with them in 
inter=
esting ways:  If you right-click on a substrate, you go into a 
mode where =
you can move the cursor around on top of the substrate in 
real time and se=
e the outgoing connections from the position of the 
cursor.  This gives yo=
u a real sense of the connectivity motifs that 
it discovered, which are su=
rprisingly diverse.  

You can also middle-click and see the total activati=
on pattern on the 
substrate for the currently-displayed trial.

This inter=
face is really useful for getting intuitions about what 
HyperNEAT is able =
to do.  You can even increase the resolution of the 
substrate and see how =
it translates connectivities to higher 
resolutions without further evoluti=
on. 

Or, you can evolve from scratch.

If you want to be really adventurou=
s of course you can create your 
own experiments.

We will update the packa=
ge over time as new results are published.

A separate C# package (derived =
from Colin Green's C# NEAT) is also 
working in our lab on a different task=
, but it still needs some 
cleaning up before release.

ken
